div1.head: Extract: The Practice of Medicine in the Tropics, by Henry Rose Carter, 1922 [Enclosed in C0312017]
div1.p:
Extract from: “The Practice of Medicine in the Tropics,”
Edited by Byam & Archibald,
Oxford Press: London, 1922.

Section on Yellow Fever, by H. R. Carter, Assistant Surgeon General,
U. S. Public Health Service.

“The demonstration of the mechanism of the conveyance of yellow
fever by the Commission, of which Reed was Chairman, at Quemados in 1900
and 1901, and its immediate acceptance by the leaders in tropical medicine
everywhere, forms a brilliant chapter in experimental medicine.

“Finlay, basing his belief on epidemiological evidence, first for-
mulated the doctrine of mosquito conveyance in 1881 and was persistent in
pressing it, with some modifications, up to its demonstration by Reed's Com-
mission. The principles of the conveyance of a micro-organism by metaxeny
were not understood, or certainly the knowledge of them was not generally
disseminated at this time, and his idea was at first that this conveyance
was a mechanical transference of a micro-organism and later a mechanical
transference modified by a proliferation (and increase in virulence) of the
micro-organism in the fruit juices and sugars adhering to the hairs etc. of
the insects mouth parts, which furnished the culture medium. He did, how-
ever, formulate the doctrine of conveyance from the sick to the well
by a mosquito contaminated by feeding on the sick man, and even selected as
the vector the species of mosquito which does carry the infection. Nor were
his opinions more guesses or clairvoyance, as has been said. They were
based on epidemiological reasoning correlated with the biology of a certain
species of mosquito--not convincing to the rest of us it is true--but enough to
✗✗suggest experimentation in proof or disproval. It is fair to admit that
his experiments were inconclusive; tending, indeed, to negative his contention.
This was due to his idea of mechanical conveyance not allowing enough time to
elapse forfrom the infection of the mosquito to its feeding on the healthy man--
i. e. for the development of the parasite in its insect host. He fully appre-
[c]iated the consequences of his doctrine and laid down rules of procedure for

the control and elimination of yellow fever, which, had they been followed,
would have led to the same sanitary results we have since attained. He
was absolutely convinced of the truth of his doctrine, so much so that it is
a question if his faith in it was increased by the results of Reed's ex-
periments.

Beauperthuy and Nott, the former especially, are frequently mentioned
as having formulated the same doctrine as Finlay, and before him. Beauper-
thuy taught that a mosquito by biting a well man produced the disease, the
insect getting the infection (or poison?) from the ‘putrid’ mud and slime of
brackiah marshes. To him yellow fever was an intoxication; the source of
infection being the ‘putrid’ marsh. Nott did not teach conveyance at all.
He thought a ‘minute insect’, living on or near the ground, entered the
body of a men and was itself the cause of yellow fever. Whether the pro-
gress of this ‘insect’ was by grownth, like mould, as Faget thought, or by
mechanical progression (legs or wings) is not stated. His idea is rather
the forerunner of the microbean origin of disease than of metaxeny. Neither
Beauperthuy nor Nott, ingenious as were their theories, are rivals of Finlay
in the promulgation of the doctrine of conveyance of yellow fever from the
sick to the well by the mosquito.
